segments.text: He knew that Mr. Stark and others like him had a certain following.
And there were some very prominent people like John Lindsay and others that knew that that was important.
And I think put up with it.
He really didn't think it was necessary.
A lot of student life.
But he changed some on that later.
Now, when I became aware of the hierarchy,
Wayne Hall was the Vice President of Academic Affairs.
Had Mr. Rutter selected him, or do you remember?
I don't.
I don't either.
What was their relationship?
It was pretty good.
Wayne was, as you know, dedicated, quiet, didn't waste a lot of words, and generally made the right decisions.
I don't recall any animosity there.
What was the guy's name that came in as the, what did they call him?
He was an engineer by nature, and he ended up back at University of Houston.
Oh, Lordy, what's his name?
He was going to be the research whiz.
Yeah.
Oh, boy.
Well, his method of operation was very, very unlike what Mr. Rutter.
I'll think of his name, too, in a minute.
He didn't use good judgment on many of his decisions.
I agree to that.
He had the faculty upset.
He had everybody upset.
On the surface, he was kind of an agreeable type of guy, but when it would come to a decision, he'd come out with some outlandish things.
Well, I remember one day at a faculty meeting of arts and sciences, he told us that the way to measure the importance of the research that anybody did was how much money did it bring in.
And somebody then asked, you mean if we're doing research that doesn't get any outside funding that it's worthless?
And he said, that's right.
And of course, those of us in history were turned off.
Did Mr. Rutter have anybody that he turned to for advice?
Tell me what you think of this.
Where he would frankly, candidly?
A lot of those were former students.
OK. That he would call, yes.
Who would be the most likely?
H.B.
Zachary would be one.
Hal Booty, John Lindsay.
Doc Daugherty, Evans.
Just a minute.
Harold Dunn.
He thought a lot of the Maltz boys.
Krueger, Polly Krueger.
Polly Krueger.
I don't know how well he knew Joe Aaron Moore.
Joe Moore was then, I think,
less active as a former student than he became.
He would call up board members too and get their advice on things.
Tom Cherry he leaned on real heavily again.
Not Hannigan.
I was trying to think of
He talked a lot with Hervey and Warris.
He probably paid more attention to former students than any president, but followed closely by Jack Williams once he got to know them.
Then they were called board of directors, not regents.
Did the directors bother him much with phone calls, letters?
No.
It was a remarkable thing, and you and I have talked before.
Those were the days, and I went to their meetings.
I didn't stay for the closed sessions where they would talk about personnel matters and things like coeducation and what have you.
But he listened very closely to Sterling Evans, had the highest regard for him.
And it scared him too because Sterling was the one that said, boys, we're not going to get by here much longer without girls.
The other thing is our library is a joke.
And that brings to mind a picture of you and I together on the top of the library at the topping out ceremony, which is the central part of the library now.
And Mr.
Rudder looked at me with a tear in his eye up there on that roof and said, Edmund, this is all the library will ever need.
That's good.
But I would put Sterling Evans way, way up high.
Another one on anything to do with the press, communications, public relations, Sam Wittenberg.
Sam wouldn't show up for the meetings, but he would call, and he kept in close touch.
And overall, with people like...

Boydle and Simons, as you and I talked about the other day, and Evans, their attitude was these were smart men that knew what to get involved in and what, as the book says, to keep their cotton-picking fingers out of.
They would want to hear why we were moving in a certain direction and the reasons behind it.
And once they believed it, they were stolidly behind.
But the president made the decision, not the board.
Can you remember any specific example of where a board member attempted to get involved or where was turned around in his ideas?
I think, and here again, boy, this is real personal, but the most troublesome board member I recall was LF Peterson.
He thought that we should beat everybody in football by a minimum of 40 points.
He would call and ask why certain plays had been called, and to please get the coach to understand not to do that again.
And I remember he would say things like, I'd be sitting there when the calls would come.
And every president's rule is, if a regent calls, put him on.
I don't care who's in the office.
And Mr. Peterson, bless his heart, I love the guy.
He was just a big overgrown boy.
Everybody's exuberant.
He said, Earl, I'm sending you five custom-made silk shirts from my tailor in Japan, and they'll be there Thursday.
Now, that's what I've done for you today.
Now, let me tell you what you're going to do for me.
And he would have some kind of a little,
pet project that he wanted.
But somewhere along in there, things began to change in terms of the relationship between the president and the chancellor, always a thorny thing, and the regents.
And I have seen it go from a well oiled machine with people that were at the top of their field, their professions.
And as you say, this was not the highlight of their career being on our board.
But they used their expertise and their knowledge and their smoothness to make it a well-functioning operation.
Not that they agreed on everything with the president, but you couldn't tell it.
But now, in more recent years, I see people that are in there for their own magnificence and spotlight and more of the political thing.
Here's what...
I'll go along with, but here's what I want from you, support for this and that.
And it looks like a committee, like a camel to me, a committee that was gone crazy.
When you first joined the staff, the board quarters were in that old Victorian house north of Sbisa.
That Mrs. Cashion was the house mother.
She was the house mother.
Red Cashion's mom.
Right, right.
And they would come there and where were the meetings held?
There was a big room up on the second floor.
The official meetings were held there?
And some of the board members were housed there and some elsewhere.
It was kind of a rank, RHIP, and the higher ranking ones, most tenure and what have you, would be there and the others would be
I guess even the Aggieland Inn, which was right across the street there, way back there, or at the Student Center.

But Ms. Cashin ran, the visitors would come in and she would sit there with them if they were going to be on the program, or they could go upstairs and sit against the wall and wait for somebody to come out and call them in.
And there was no open meeting then.
Not per se.
But the average visitor couldn't walk in?
No, no.
That's what I thought.
They'd be called in for their business.
Mr.
Rudder said, now, these old boys are doing this for nothing.
They're giving us our time, and we need to be real nice.
And so I'm going to start a new program.
Cooper, you're in charge.
We have the meats laboratory, the dairy laboratory, and I'm going to tell them what we've got out there, and when they come in,
You give them a little paper.
I worked out that system where they could, here's what you could order.
It was mainly wheels of cheese and any kind of meat product.
What was their favorite?
The wheels of cheese always sold out.
And the dairy people, Mr. Parrot, I remember, was his name.
finally learned that he damn sure better hold back when he'd see a board meeting coming up instead of selling it.
But they'd buy backstrap off the cattle.
What do you call it?
What's the fillet?
Backstrap.
And Mr. Peterson would want every wheel of cheese that was available.
And it seemed like Sterling Evans would buy
15 or 20 back straps.
They used them for entertainment, and said, this is Aggie, the best we have, and so forth.
Now, they paid for it.
Oh, yeah, they paid for it.
Yeah, they paid for it, but they got good prices.
But my job was to gather that up as they left and make sure they... Walford Kane was a sweet old man.
He was on the board, and I'll never forget a funny, sad thing that a student driver...
slammed the station wagon door on Mr. King's fingers.
And instead of screaming, he just kept saying, get the door open.
He says, it's closed on my fingers.
At any rate, you'd go all the way from what was fun to see the personalities as reflected in what they wanted, what they would buy.
And Mr. Clyde Thompson from Dybal, which he was not one of our real heavyweights on the board.
And I'm sure he was part of the old timber syndicate over there.
And all these other guys would be ordering full tenderloins and what have you.
And they'd say, Edwin, you reckon out at the poultry farm they've got eggs?
I said, yes, sir, they've got eggs.
He said, you reckon they've got them big old brown ones?
I said, yes.
I said, how many do you want?
He says, a dozen.
But to see someone like Evans contrast with some of the weak sisters that were political expedience was really funny.
And I always remember everybody called him Doc Boydle.
Never could be seen at a meeting without his hand computer.
Everything that was said, he would double check it
Check the mathematics of it.
The mathematics of it.

And I think Mr. Evans through all the years probably did the best job of manipulating President Rutter of any of them to the tune that the library really was inadequate and that we would never really reach our potential without girls.
And I think
Gracefully, he was able to show Mr.
Rudder the reality, because though he never looked me in the eye, I am convinced that Earl Rudder really wanted a very fine West Point type activity here in College Station.
But he finally realized that wasn't going to fly.
And then the most memorable thing he ever told me was, I don't remember whether it was just on one trip, but
He stayed at the White House when Mr. Johnson was there, right at that time, mid-60s, when all the big decisions were about to be made.
And he told me that he went to Lyndon Johnson and said, I'm not as good on timing as I should be, but coeducation, integration, blacks, name change,
to the university, and non-compulsory core, the big four.
And over whiskey, he said to Lyndon Johnson, primarily the coeducation thing, I think, was he said, what do you think about it?
And the way he said it to me was, he said, Earl, you can do it your way now or our way later, and you're going to like your way a lot better than you're going to like ours.
I'm glad to hear it.
Now, when he came back, he'd made up his mind then that the change had to take place.
But he wanted even then to do it very gradually.
And that's the way it worked right at first.
Mr. Heaton was petrified to put it in the catalog and did not for three years.
But he came back and the board told him when they were ready to make these big decisions
The board said, and I hope I'm right on this, and I think I am, said, Earl, get in with those alumni, and we want them to support us in advance of this decision.
And John Lindsay was president.
And he went to some of the biggest squabblers about it and said, now look, now you keep your damn mouth shut, but I had the president of America tell me that it has to be done
If we want to do it our way, we can do that.
Now, we need you, and you're the one that's squabbling.
Now, the main trouble was in Dallas and Beaumont.
And there was a certain amount of diploma burning, and not much, not near as much as people laid on, senior ranks and that.
But when he came back with that story and said, look, what alternatives do we have?
He said, in effect, this is not what I want necessarily.
But it's what's going to happen.
Now, this was after you were working for him.
And then, let me finish that story.
I think it was this same trip where you ask him that, of these questions.
And he let him know what kind of a tight situation he was in.
And just as a side note, something really big in international policy came up, and Lyndon was called away from his usual goodnight drink with whoever his guests were
He said, just stand by.
He said, we'll get this damn thing solved one way or another.
We're going to have some whiskey tonight.
And it went on and on and on, and Mr.
Rudder got bored.
He could not sit still.
Could not.
And he picked up a newspaper there in the White House, and at a theater not four blocks away was a theater on the roof, and he'd been wanting to see that.
So he got all of the...
protocol of leaving the White House grounds.
He had all that worked out and his passes and everything.
He went to the picture show and saw Fiddler on the Roof and at five, about five in the morning, he said that phone by his bed rang and it says, Earl Rudder, you son of a bitch, he said.
The President of the United States of America wants to drink whiskey with you and you go out and see Fiddler on the Roof.
The SS people knew exactly where he went.
Oh, yeah.
Oh, sure, sure.
And reported back to him.
And that was the funny part.
But I think that was the trip where he did that several times.
But they were really, sure enough, close.
I mean, as close as you can get.
And I remember, I think you were already working for him.
There was going to be a referendum of students on these questions.
But there wasn't going to be a faculty referendum.
And we were really frustrated.
The day before that referendum, by luck, there was a regular fall meeting of all arts and sciences faculty, or fall or spring, over in the chemistry lecture hall.
And Mr. Rutter spoke.
And in his speech, he didn't say a thing about those key questions.
And so as there were question and answer, nobody touched it.
And finally, they said, we've got time for one more question.
I raised my hand.
And I was scared so that my voice quivered as I asked, why didn't you ask the faculty for their vote on this?
And Mr. Rutter said, hell, I didn't need to ask you all.
I know you're all for those changes.
And everybody kind of cheered.
And seven years later, when I was in his office begging for money for the library, I mentioned that to him, if he remembered that question.
And he said, yes, and I remember how scared you were.
So I give him excellent marks for that.
Are there any other people that you can think of who deserve mention as being key co-education, non-compulsory, co-racial integration?
Well, John Lindsay, I would say...
He was former student president during that.
Right, and I was at the meeting in the...
What did they call the big meeting room right at the end of the hall on the second floor?
The ballroom was there, but the... Birch room.
I guess.
Down at the east end of the second floor?
Yes.
That was a birch room.
Everybody was on pins and needles because they knew this was coming up.
This is the former student board?
It was their winter board meeting.
Oh, yes.
And I was there.
Summarize it.
And John Lindsay was as pale as that paper.

because there'd been a lot of hard talk about this, and that the school was going to hell, and that the alumni were not going to, when it came down to it, they were not going to vote to endorse the board's impending decision before it happened.
They wanted support.
And so I was there, and I'm telling you,
We were all on pins and needles.

And I guess there had been a little bit of skullduggery maybe on someone to make the motion and someone to second the motion that they support coeducation at Texas A&M University, support the board's impending decision to do that.
And Lindsey made the,
the preliminary remarks and then said, do I hear a motion?
And someone immediately snapped up.
And there was an immediate second.
And there was an immediate all in favor and all opposed.
There was not a whisper of opposition.
And Lindsay slammed that gavel and was the most got out of there faster than a speeding bullet.
But it went through.
That's what I had heard.
Yeah.
And that Wirus and Hervey.

had helped yeah uh right and that as i understand that the former student action may have helped move another board of directors vote or two there may have been one or two of those people that yeah so do you know of any uh director who officially opposed any uh opposed the uh
Those major decisions?
I've never heard of anybody who officially opposed it.
No.
If there was, it was behind closed doors.
And he sure said nothing about it.
But I think the key to it all was Rutter's strategy, and I knew he knew what Lyndon Johnson was going to say.
But when he came back with the President of America saying these things, what could you do?
I've never heard that.
You've highlighted my day already with that.
Tell me how, as far as you know, how did he start racial integration?
I've heard that he called the Pentagon and that when they sent some enlisted men that one summer to begin their

finish their degree that some of them were black okay here's what comes to mind and i hadn't thought of this a major united states army was assigned to the rotc the commandant's office and he came down for a preliminary trip mainly to find housing
somewhere close to the campus.
And he was denied by everybody.
Because he was black?
Because he was black.
The nicest, as I remember, a very nice man.
Today it would be just such a foolish thing, you wouldn't even, you couldn't believe it happened.
But now here's what I think happened.
Earl Rudder called one of his local honchos, Jack Connolly, by the way, was a big, they were real close, and Connolly was mayor.
But he called John Cecil Culpepper Sr.
He said, Culpepper, we're going to find out what you're made out of.
You've got all these little houses over there, you know, over there by the, they were kind of new then, by the theater, the mud lot, right in there.
He said...
I not only want you to find this major a place to live in your property, but I want you to get the Real Estate Association undercover any way you want to do it.
Let's get rid of this crap.
He said, we're going to have black people in here, and you might as well just grow up to it right now.
I need your help.
And he did.
At the risk of all sorts of ridicule, he did it, though.
Now, that's my memory of how it happened.

As I recall, the first black students to enroll was in a summer, and that some of them were regular army enlisted men who had been sent here by the Pentagon, and that Mr. Heaton, somebody I understood, told Mr. Heaton, you get on the phone Monday, registration day, and call the instructors that will have any of them in class,
to tell them that those students are admitted, they have been admitted, they're OK. And so when they are in your class tomorrow, Tuesday of summer school, there is no.
Just saying that part of it, I had no contact with that at all.
All right.
I think I'll know the answer to this question.
Tell me any of the major incidents you recall on the campus of black students attending class.
I don't remember one.
No.
There weren't any that I know of.

When Rutter asked me in 67 to go out and develop a program for the non-core students when we knew we were going to swing that way with girls and non-military type students, and he asked me to do that.
I've got something I want to give you on that.
How nice.
That's from Abby?
Yes, it's from Abby.
Beautiful.
Joyce and Shelly and Sharon Cash and all got a hold of my girls and said, take care of your mother.
When I went over there, there were two civilian student activities in 1967 to develop a program for non-core students.
And we call them civilian students, because that's what they call themselves.
Very proudly.

Very shortly after I was on that job and the announcements were made that I was there to help develop programs for non-core students, a pretty down-in-the-mouth couple of black boys came by and said, we don't believe what you all are saying about us being welcome here.
And I said, well, why don't we get close together and at least have a chance to

express a view you from the standpoint of the black students me from the standpoint of what i think the administration is saying that's what my job is and i formed the first black student advisory committee and i am telling you haskell monroe that our first few meetings were just short of violent because they truly believed could not believe though they'd had no
stress could not believe that the university was serious about integration.
Now, these were students enrolled, full-time students.
They were not athletes.
They were some of our first black undergraduate students.
But they anticipated problems.
Yes, they did.
And if I ever read people's faces, I can tell you they did not trust me at first.
And gradually, we were able, when I say here is why this is happening, here's why, they finally began to trust me some.
And eventually, because of the way things moved along, I think, in a positive way, they just quit meeting.
I think they were satisfied that things were going to get better.
In those years working closely with Mr. Rutter, other than coeducation,
Voluntary Corps and name change and so forth.
What do you think were his other greatest steps of pride, things that happened that he was most proud of?
His connections with Teague and Moore and Clayton and others.
One thing he was tremendously proud of was the amount of state and federal funding that he was able to get for the institution.
And he really believed in this thing that came about, the study you were involved with, is we are going for excellence to do that.
We need a first class faculty, first class student body.
That affects admission standards.
We need facilities.
He probably did more for facilities at that time than all the other presidents put together.
And he had the connections to do it.
Other things that he took pride in, through his connections, Teague, for example.
